title: Dias
common: The surname Dias does not have a unique origin, because it is a patronymic meaning "Diego's son" or "Diogo's son". There is also an additional issue, when an indigenous became Christian, they could also receive the surname Dias. This complexity conducts Américo de Moura to list 10 different Dias' families (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 345-348), but documents published years later shown some of them were relatives (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23).

families.name: Dias (São Vicente)
history: Lopo Dias and Beatriz Dias' family

people.name: Lopo Dias
history: He lived in Santo André during the years of 1555 and 1558 (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 346), but he was already in São Paulo in the year of 1562 (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 17). He had a long life, he was still alive when his son passed away in the year of 1609 (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113).

On this site we are showing him only with surname Dias, because he signed documents only with it (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 17, 19, 39, 91, 93, 105, 108,109, 344, 345), we cannot discard that when necessary he could also sign Machado as his brother, Rui Dias Machado, cited in the canonization document of Priest Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23). In 21st century, because we sign all surnames, we had the illusion that people always had his pattern, but this is a new event for the Portuguese language that did not have criteria well established during centuries (Monteiro, Nuno G., 2008 ; Gonçalves, Iria.).

Another fact easy to detect in Lopo Dias' life is his relationship with the Christian faith. He was one of the inhabitants that signed to build the Church of the city (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 344, 345), while in his last days he was part of "Ordem Carmelita" (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 133, 141-142; Castro Coelho, H. V., 1994, pp. 111).

José G. Salvador supposed he was a Jewish because "O apelido, lobo, era adotado por muitos que descendiam da tribo de Benjamin" [the surname, lobo, was used by many descendants of Benjamin tribe] (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 132, 197), but it is known that the Qasi's family, that is a Visigoth family that became Islamic, also had people named Lobo/Lubb (Flórez, Henriques, 1756, p. 488; Crônica de Afonso III, pp. 9,16 ; Banu Qasi, History Tracers). Continuing with his hypothesis, José G. Salvador says there was a homonymous, "Lopo Dias", Jewish (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 132, 197), but as we already said, there is not a unique Dias family, and Lopo Dias is also part of Machado's family (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23). The whole hypothesis does not have a unique primary source to support it, but it looks like there is a link with a partial primary source (Torre do Tombo, Mesa da Consciência e Ordens, Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66; Bogaciovas, Marcelo M. A, 2015, pp. 279-280) that is cited without to explicit the issue to be partial, it is also appended an additional novel that there were a lawfare in another religious habilitation "falcatruas que se processou na habilitação do homônimo" [lawfare happened during homonymous diligences] (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 31, 32). The conclusion that this partial primary source cannot be used to prove any Jewish ancestor is exposed in a diligence for Inquisition familiar of Pedro Dias Paes, son of Garcia Roiz Paes, in this document a witness that had access to Garcia Roiz Paes complete document gives details about defamation during the war between the Pires and Camargo (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28, 47, 48, 66-69).

marriages.name: Beatriz Dias
history: Cited for her daughter during Priest José de Anchieta's canonization documents (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23) and for her son in his inventory (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113).

There is not any doubt about her marriage due to her children's declarations, but we have doubts about her parents, so I am going to do two different citations for her. Firstly we consider her a possible daughter of Tibiriçá (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume IX, pp. 67)

marriages.name: Beatriz Dias
history: Cited for her daughter during Priest José de Anchieta's canonization documents (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23) and for her son in his inventory (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113).

Instead, Tibiriçá, she could be a João Ramalho's daughter (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34), in this hypothesis Silva Leme names her Beatriz Ramalho (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34)

children.name: Suzana Dias
history: According to priest José de Anchieta's canonization documents (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 35).

children.name: Belchior Carneiro
history: According to his own words (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34).

people.name: Suzana Dias
history: According to her words in her testament, she marriages two times, and she had 17 children, all children from the first marriage with Manuel Fernandes Ramos (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 12,13).
She was one of the witness of the canonization of Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23).

I would like to call attention to the relationship between Suzana Dias and her children with indigenous: in her inventory it is possible to observe that she gave freedom to an indigenous, but she also gave other indigenous to other sons (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 13,14) and during wartimes André Fernandes took indigenous people from Francisco Camargo (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 94). Everything happened besides the fact they had indigenous as ancestors (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443).
A research not finalized is showing that her mitocondrial haplogroup is C1b (subgroup) (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 01:07:10).

marriages.name: Manoel Fernandes Ramos
history: According her own words (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 12,13).

families.name: Dias (Cachoeira do Campo)
history: This family has origin with Bento Dias, that lived as an 'aggregated' person in Anna Theodora Pinto's house in Cachoeira do Campo - Minas Gerais (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1824, Fogos 10).

people.name: Bento Dias
history:
It was not possible to collect deep information about this person, the available data are present in population maps where it was possible to observe that:
  • In the year 1824 he was cited as an aggregated person in Anna Theodora Pinto's house (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1824, Fogos 10).
  • In year 1831 he was already in marriage to Anastácia, and he was living on Maria Úrsula da Silva's land, lady Maria gave freedom to Anastácia (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1831, Fogos 22). After changing his residence, Bento Dias adopted the surname Silva.
  • In 1838, Bento and his wife already had their own residence ('Fogo'). Bento's age, on the other hand, looks like wrong, because he is only one year older than his wife, while he was 5 years old in two previous population maps. Anastácia's age is correct (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1838, Fogos 83), but she changed her name in this population map.

marriages.name: Anastasia
history: According to population map (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1838, Fogos 83).

children.name: João Anastácio Dias
history: According to his baptism (Paróquia Nossa Senhora de Nazaré, 1847.)

families.name: Dias (Indígena - Bahia)
history: During centuries, and still nowadays, there is the wish from overall people to have a specific group of people as ancestors to avoid miscegenation (Schneider, Alberto L., 2016, pp. 99, 100), as consequence of these wishes, some histories are rewritten, this would be an issue for a Luiz G. Silva Leme propose (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 03), but recent research changed the initial understanding about what happened.

people.name: Pedro Dias
history: Américo de Moura informs that Pedro Taques reported a Portuguese named Pedro Dias had a marriage with an indigenous named Maria da Grã (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 347), this narrative was followed by another genealogist, Luiz G. Silva Leme, that reports "Pedro Dias, da família — Parente Dias Velho —, de Portugal, veio a São Vicente como irmão leigo da Companhia de Jesus" [Pedro Dias, from Family - Parente Dias Velho -, from Portugal, came to São Vicentte as part of Jesuits] (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 03), but the Priest Serafim Leite in his work "História da Companhia de Jesus" cites "Em 1566, estava na Baia, o Irmão Pedro Dias, ainda noviço, nascido aqui na terra" [In 1566, Pedro Dias was in Bahia, he was still a novice, and he was born in Brazil] (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias"), adding that the idea he was marriage with an indigenous would be a novel.
Another propose more coherent with possible facts was presented by H. V. Castro Coelho (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias").
In this section, we treat only the novice.

marriages.name: Terebé/Maria da Grã
history: A hypothesis that was part of a novel according to Priest Serafim Leite (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias").

families.name: Dias - Índigenas (Espírito Santo - Fundão)
history: In the 8th edition of magazine Genea published in the year 2020, the researcher/genealogist Gilber Rubim Rangel brought data about the "devassa" executed by Jesuits (Rangel, Gilber R., 2020, pp. 75-116), and among the people listed in the paper, we have indigenous signing surname Dias.

people.name: Jerônimo Dias
history: He was killed in prison (Rangel, Gilber R., 2020, pp. 96).
